newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania asks Germany to invest more.
newsitem.headline: Romania asks Germany to invest more.

text.p: Romania's centrist coalition government told German businessmen their investment was needed to ensure the success of overdue market reforms.

"Without serious foreign investment we will not overcome the economic and social crisis," Prime Minister Victor Ciorbea told 600 local and German businessmen in Bucharest on Wednesday during a visit by German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel.
"Romania will continue to need help. The most precious support we can get now is the trust to invest in Romania."
Romania, Eastern Europe's second largest market after Poland, has attracted far less foreign investment than other ex-communist countries.
Total direct foreign investment since 1989 stood at $2.3 billion early in April, with 97 percent of it in small businesses.

The centrists, who defeated leftists in elections last year, have promised incentives and improved legislation aimed at benefiting companies which invest a minimum $10 million in Romania, instead of $50 million at present.
They include tax breaks, extension of customs duties holidays and free acquisition of land and production spaces.
"We are determined to simplify administrative measures, cut bureaucracy, check corruption and propose new incentives for businessmen," Foreign Minister Adrian Severin said.

Germany was Romania's largest commercial partner in 1996, with two-way trade amounting to $5.6 billion. It is the second largest foreign investor with investments worth $220 million and 6,000 joint ventures.
Romania has already adopted a law allowing foreigners to own land and pledged amendments to legislation to simplify investment procedures.
